Comment: So it's not a politics thing, its actually a stagecraft thing honed from decades of data from the television and film industry.   Here's just one of the studies that highlights this phenomenon.   https://www.researchgate.net/publication/228448619_Which_Way_Did_He_Go_Directionality_of_Film_Character_and_Camera_Movement_and_Subsequent_Spectator_Interpretation  The TLDR of it is:   How we visually analyze something is strongly tied to our cultural environment. For Americans, thats largely influenced by how we teach our children to read: from left to right.   When watching content on a visual medium like television, moving from left to right on the screen feels natural to us, and more commonly elicits a "positive" reception of the content.   Moving from right to left however, feels unnatural and subconsciously our brain interprets it as "negative" reception of the content.   Politicians want to be on the right hand of the screen because it takes advantage of this little tidbit of stagecraft knowledge.   How much effect that marginal interpretation of our subconscious actually plays in our decision making is probably negligible when it comes to politics.   But any campaign manager worth their salt will take any chance, marginal or not, to benefit their candidate in whatever way they can.
